A variant infection involving head, face and hair follicles. This is characterized by the appearance of one or more papule at the root of hair follicle which gets encrusted and later takes the shape of ulcer.

An ulcerated form of Sa‘fa from which there is continuous discharge of purulent fluid. It is more commonly seen in children. It is caused by viscous, putrified, irritant and bad humours which causes swelling and ulceration of skin.
A dry form of Sa‘fa in which there is white scaling of skin. It is caused by black bile mixed with pungent humour which sharpens the nature of the disease.
A type of Sa‘fa Raṭba. In this condition, the scalp becomes honey comb like in appearance with small openings which are filled with fluid. It is accompanied with hair loss.
A type of Sa‘fa. Its literal meaning is “tip of needle”. The papules are similar to tip of needle with swelling of the root of hair follicle from which there is discharge of fluid mixed with blood.
A type of Sa‘fa which resembles fig in appearance. There is round ulcerated portion within the papules similar to that of fig.
A type of Sa‘fa which occurs in semi lunar shape and are red in colour.
A bad and chronic type of Sa‘fa which is caused by morbid humours.

Name English: ulceration of the scalp hair roots with intense redness
Long_definition: A red coloured Sa‘fa involving the skin of scalp. It is painful and appears after shaving the head. According to Galen, if it is suppurated, it cannot be treated.

Name English: spasm of skin of the forehead with itching and redness
Long_definition: Spasm of the skin of forehead which causes wrinkles on the forehead. It is more commonly seen in winter season. It is characterized by burning and itching.
Injury of the toe due to stumbling on the road.

Swelling and itching of the fingers in winter season. It commonly occurs in individuals having bilious temperament. During winter season the skin pores are closed and there is thickening of skin due to which morbid material get accumulated in the skin of fingers.
Itching of the fingers.
An infection caused by the continous dampening in between the fingers.
A foul smell of axilla and groin region. It is caused by the putrefaction of the humours of body. It is also due to strenuous physical activity especially after over indulgence in sex.

Foul smell in the scalp due to hypersecretion and putrefaction of the sebaceous glands. The condition is more commonly seen in children because of the presence of considerable amount of fluid in them. In older people this condition arises due to the decrease in the innate energy of the body.

Arabic_term: خصر و تصقيع/ فساد الاطراف بالبرد
Long_definition: In countries that have a cold climate there is thickening of the skin of hand, feet, face which sometimes get resolved and sometimes gets ulcerated and detaches after developing gangrene.

Hard eruptions on the surface of the skin. If the edges of these eruptions are circular, then these are known as Masāmīr. If the edges are slanting, these are known as Qurūn. These are produced by the predominance of viscous phlegm.

Arabic_term: بثور لبنيہ / حب الشباب /بثور دہنیہ /الغد الشائع
NAMC_TERM: Buthūr Labaniyya/ Ḥabb al-Shabāb/ Buthūr Duhniyya/ Al-Ghudd al-Shā’i‘
Long_definition: Sometimes there is an appearance of white papules on face and nose accompanied by discharge of viscous fluids from them.These are mostly due to the inflammation of hair follicles and their accompanying sebaceous glands in young people.

It is the abnormal heating of the body which after reaching the heart from any part of the body spreads to other organs through vessels. This abnormal heating interferes with the vital faculties of the body.
A type of fever which lasts only for few days. It is a transient and short term fever.
A type of fever that occurs due to severe apprehension.
A type of fever that occurs due to fear and fright as these gestures aggravates the heat of the body.
A type of fever that occurs due to profound anxiety.
A type of fever that occurs due to excessive anger. The fever is characterized by red swollen face, red congested eyes, high pulse volume, red urine and may cause burning.
A type of fever that occurs due to excessive happiness and joy.
A type of transient fever that occurs due to sleep deprivation. This is accompanied with sunken eyes, puffy eyelids, palor face, swollen body, low volume pulse.
A type of transient fever that occurs due to excessive physical exertion and fatigue.

A type of transient fever that occurs due to excessive loss of fluids because of loose motions. In this type of fever patient will give history of loose motion or use of any drug which causes loose motion.
A type of transient fever that occurs due to excessive pain.
A type of transient fever that occurs due to fainting and coma.
A type of fever that occurs due to excessive thirst over a long time.
A type of fever that occurs due to excessive starvation over a long time. This is characterized by low feeble pulse.

Name English: Ephemeral fever due to occlusion of blood vessels
Long_definition: A type of transient fever that occurs due to obstruction of blood vessels. This is the only type of transient fever which can last up to three days and can transform into Ḥummā ‘Ufūnī i.e. infectious fever. The temperature in this type is higher than any other fever, pulse rate becomes faster, urine become dark.
A type of transient fever that occurs due to dyspepsia and indigestion. In this there is increased sore eructation.
A type of fever that results due to ulcers, wounds, injuries, boils, abscesses, etc.

Name English: Ephemeral fever due to heat stroke
Long_definition: A type of transient fever that results from the long exposure to sun or travelling under the sun. In this the eyes become congested, pulse small and fast.

Name English: ephemeral fever due to lack of perspiration
Long_definition: A type of transient fever caused by the closure of the skin pores due to cold environment, bathing with excessively cold water or water in which astringent drugs are added e.g. alum. In this condition, the skin becomes thickened, face and eyes are swollen, pulse becomes rapid, and urine becomes concentrated and yellow in colour.
A type of transient fever that occurs due to the intake of pure alcohol. In this condition eyes and face become congested and there will be burning at the site of liver.
A type of fever that occurs due to the intake of hot diets rich in spices.

Name English: ephemeral fever due to certain drugs
Long_definition: A type of fever that occurs due to the intake of drugs of hot temperament.

Name English: ephemeral fever due to discontinuing abstinence from bathing
Long_definition: A type of transient fever that occurs due to closure of skin pores by dirt and dust because of abstinence from bathing.
A type of fever that occurs due to cold and coryza.
A type of fever that occurs due to dysentery.
Transient fever due to exposure to extreme heat.

Arabic_term: حمیٰ اليوم نوميہ/ حمیٰ اليوم راحيہ
NAMC_TERM: Ḥummā al-Yawm Nawmiyya/ Ḥummā al-Yawm Rāḥiyya
Long_definition: This type of transient fever occurs due to prolonged sleep. The patient will give a history of excessive sleep and less physical exertion. Pulse will be voluminous.
This occurs due to trauma or injury of the body.
This type of fever occurs due to the accumulation of bad humours in the body.

Name English: ephemeral fever due to excessive evacuation
Long_definition: Transient fever due to excessive evacuation.
A specific type of fever which gradually destroys the fluids and weakens the organs of the body and causes weight loss.
A type of fever in which the temperature of the humours of body usually rises because of putrefaction. From here it goes towards heart and then spreads to other organs of the body.

The abnormal changes occurring in the humours and body due to obnoxious substances that affect their normal functioning. Sometimes these changes occur inside the vessels i.e. Dākhil al-‘Urūq and when these changes occur outside the vessels these are known as Khārij al-‘Urūq.
When the putrefaction of the humours occurs inside the vessels i.e. Dākhil al-‘Urūq then the fever remains continuous.
When the putrefaction of the humours occurs outside the vessels i.e. Khārij al-‘Urūq then it results in the fever of non-continuous nature.
A type of fever that occurs due to the predominance of Ṣafrā’ (yellow bile) in the body. It is of three types i.e. Ghibb Dā’ira, Ghibb Lāzima and Ghibb Muḥarriqa.

When the putrefaction of yellow bile occurs outside the vessels then the attack of fever occurs after three days or approximately 48 hours. The attack usually starts with rigors and chills. It is accompanied with headache, excessive thirst, restlessness, bilious vomiting and sometimes, bilious diarrhoea. Pulse in the initial stage is irregular and later on, it becomes rapid and strong and urine is reddish and sharp smelling. This fever subsides with sweating and the attack of fever is of short duration usually 4-6 hours and sometimes it extends upto 12 hours. This type of fever has got good prognosis similar to ephemeral fever.

When the putrefaction of Ṣafrā’ (yellow bile) occurs within the vessels then the fever is continuous in nature and lasts for 5-14 days. But meanwhile there is relief in symptoms for few hours. The fever is usually high with or without rigors and chills. Before the onset of fever patient feels nausea and restlessness. In this stage the face and eyes of the patient becomes red and congested, experiences excessive thirst, bilious vomiting, pulse rapid, urine red, scanty. This fever subsides in the form of Buḥrān.

When the fever and its related symptom are more severe as compared to tertian fever. In this condition, the patient’s tongue becomes rough, black, fever is continuous in nature, and there is restlessness, confusion, excessive thirst and bilious vomiting. This type of fever occurs mostly in children and young people.

A type of septic phlegmatic fever whose attacks occur on consecutive days. This starts with severe rigors and chills. Temperature is not very high. Pulse is low and irregular accompanied with oedematous body, phlegmatic vomiting, diarrhoea and viscous urine. It affects persons with phlegmatic temperament i.e. children and older people.
The attack of septic phlegmatic fever occurs twice in a day.
When there is involvement of yellow bile in phlegm the symptoms of fever are more severe.
In this condition there is no rigor and chills. The symptoms are more or less same as that of Ḥummā Muwāẓiba.

A type of septic melancholic fever in which subsequent attack occurs every four day. This is a type of intermittent fever because the putrefaction of black bile occurs outside the vessels. The fever occurs mostly in summer season. The fever starts with mild rigors and chills and lasts for 24 hours. It is associated with joint pain, there is involvement of spleen, hardness of pulse and excessive thirst.

A type of fever that occurs when there is putrefaction of black bile inside the vessels. In this type, fever is continuous, but on the fourth day it reaches to higher degree. The attack of fever is not associated with rigors and chills. This type of fever is usually rare.
A type of fever that does not follow a particular pattern. This occurs due to inflammation of organs.
A type of humoral fever in which the patient feels heat outside the body but cold from inside.
A type of humoral fever in which the patient feels heat inside the body but cold from outside. It is of two type; moderate and severe.
A type of Ḥummā Līfūriya, caused due to the predominance of Ṣafrā’ (yellow bile).
A fever that combines the features of Afyālūs and Līfūriya.
A type of fever that is sanguinous in nature and rises with the passage of time. It is of two types: Muṭbiqa Ghalayāniyya and Muṭbiqa ‘Ufūniyya.

A type of fever that occurs due to the involvement of blood. The fever starts without rigors and chills. The symptoms are similar to the symptoms produced due to the predominance of blood in the body.

A type of fever occurring due to severe putrefaction or sepsis. It is of three types: 1. Mutazā’ida, in which the symptoms gradually increases till the onset of fever, 2. Mutanāqiṣa, in which the symptoms gradually decreases till the onset of fever, 3. Mutasāwiya, in which the symptoms remain same till the onset of fever.
When the attack of fever repeats after five days.
When the attack of fever repeats after six days.
When the attack of fever repeats after seven days.
When the attack of fever repeats after nine days.
A type of fever accompanied with altered sensorium because the causative humour i.e. phlegm and yellow bile affects the brain of the patient.
A type of continuous and infectious fever which involves intestines. It usually lasts for 21 days or more and small eruptions appear on the skin.
A type of fever which affects the population of a particular area during a specific period. It is caused by water, air or soil pollution.
A type of fever that is accompanied with eruptions of different colours and sizes.
A severe infectious disease which spreads in the form of epidemic. In this condition, there is a high degree of fever and eruptions appear after three days.

An infectious fever which is continuous in nature. This is accompanied with eruptions and infections of nasal cavity. Eruptions are scattered all over the body but are not big in size and similar to millet.
An infectious type of fever with eruptions of crimson red colour. This is usually accompanied with inflammation of throat and kidney.

Arabic_term: حمیٰ غاميہ هذيانيہ /حمیٰ رقطہ /حمیٰ السفن /حمیٰ قذرہ /حمیٰ السجون
NAMC_TERM: Ḥummā Ghāmiya Hadhayāniyya/Ḥummā Ruqṭa/ Ḥummā al-Sufun /Ḥummā Qadhira/Ḥummā al-Sujūn
Name English: Fever due to unhygienic living condition
Long_definition: A type of eruptive fever without the involvement of any organ. There is marked weakness. Sometimes there is congestion of lungs. Living in unhygienic condition, damp places and malnutrition are predisposing causes of this fever. This fever is accompanied with delirium and coma.

A type of eruptive fever in which the symptoms are not severe. The eruptions are colourless, bigger in size. Fever is usually not high. There is no marked weakness. It is not accompanied with delirium and coma.

Name English: Fever due to sweet and saline or vitreous or sour phlegm
Long_definition: A type of fever caused by Balgham Zujājī (vitreous phlegm) and Balgham Shor (saline phlegm). This fever does not last for a long time.
A type of melancholic fever which occurs after five, six, seven, eight or nine days.

Name English: Bleeding under skin due to fever
Long_definition: Haemorrhages occurring beneath the skin, petechial or bigger in size and caused by fevers e.g. Ḥummā Ghāmiyya, etc.
A type of infectious fever caused by the organism found in the stagnant water. This is characterised by enlargement of spleen.

Pain of the back can be superficial or deep. It can be due to cold impaired temperament, predominance of phlegm, physical exertion, incorrect sitting posture, increased sexual activity, weakness of kidneys, premenstrual pain, labour pain, congestion of portal vein and aorta.
Pain of the lower portion of back.
Inflammation and pain of joints with redness of the skin. Sometimes it involves heart.

A type of arthalgia which involves several joints. As per involvement of humours it is of four types i.e. Damawī, Balghamī, Ṣafrāwī and Sawdāwī. According to severity of symptoms it is again divided into acute and chronic type. When two humours are involved this is known as Waja‘ al-Mafāṣil Murakkab.
Pain of hip joint. Its causes are same as Waja‘ al-Mafāṣil.
Severe pain in the heel which is also known as Nuzūl al-Mā’ i.e. infiltration of water. It is caused by the infiltration of acrid humours after pain.

A specific type of swelling and pain that occurs in foot specially great toe. But sometimes it may affect wrist and fingers of hand also. According to Ibn Hubal, toe joints are known as Inqūrūs from which the word Niqris been derived. It is a heredity disease.

A type of pain which originates from the hip joints and runs along with the sciatic nerve. Intensity of pain increases with the quantity of matter.This pain causes wasting of the muscles of legs due to disuse.
The ossification of joints and reduced joint spaces leading to locking of the joints.
A deformity in which there is backward bending of the vertebral column.
Forward bending of chest.
Dislocation of vertebral column at one side.

Displacement of vertebral column commonly seen in tubercular patients. In this a chronic ulcer damages the vertebral column up to the gangrenous stage. Due to this destruction, there is displacement of vertebral column.

Arabic_term: وهن العظام/ تخلخل العظام/ تخثر العظام
NAMC_TERM: Wahn al-‘Iẓām/ Takhalkhul al-‘Iẓām/ Takhaththur al-‘Iẓām
Long_definition: It means weakness of bones in old age or pain of bones after trauma and injury. Bones are more prone to fractures in this condition.
Discontinuity/breaking of bones.
In this condition, only the bone is broken and there is no discontinuity of skin and mucous membrane.
Breakage of bone associated with skin and mucous membrane. There is laceration of skin by the fragments of broken bone.
Breakage or discontinuity of bone along with the involvement of surrounding organs either artery or vein. It is either due to trauma from outside or puncture by the fragments of broken bones.
Complete breakage or discontinuity of the bone.

NAMC_TERM: Kasr Ghayr Kāmil/ Kasr Juz’ī Kāmil
Long_definition: Incomplete breaking or discontinuity of the bone.
The fracture of bone longitudinally. It occurs mostly in flat bones e.g. skull, scapula, etc. It is usually too small to trace.

An incomplete type of fracture which occurs mostly in children or ribs of older people. It resembles the breaking of fresh green branch of tree which when bended gets partially broken with some of its fibres remaining intact.
Crushing of a single bone into many pieces.
Breaking of bone with injury by some sharp objects and exposure of a piece of bone outside.
A perforating type of breakage of bone.
In this type of fracture, breaking occurs longitudinally or in the length of bone.
In this type of fracture, breaking of bone occurs transversally.
In this type of fracture breaking of bone occurs obliquely.
In this type of fracture, breaking of bone occurs in twisted manner or spiral manner.
A type of fracture in which broken long bones penetrate into the soft tissue.
The fracture of bones of foetus inside the uterus due to the trauma to the abdomen of expecting women.
Fracture of the bones of a new born due to bad obstetric procedure.
In this type, there is a thinline fracture of bones.
A fracture that occurs in the bones due to some disease.
Fracture of the edges of bones.
Fracture of nasal bone.

Arabic_term: كسر فجلي/ كسر قصبي/ كسر قثوى
Long_definition: Deep and broad fracture of the bones.
Broad and long fracture of bones.

Arabic_term: كسر سويقي/ كسر قضيبي/ كسر جوزي/ كسر جريشي
NAMC_TERM: Kasr Sawīqī/ Kasr Qaḍībī/ Kasr Jawzī/ Kasr Jarīshī
Long_definition: Crushed fracture of the bones.
It is the slipping out of a bone from joint.
Dislocation of joints caused by two factors i.e. exogenous and endogenous. Exogenous factors, include trauma of the joint. Endogenous factors include the weakness of joint, ligaments etc.
Total deviation or displacement of bone from its adjoining bone.

A type of dislocation which is present at birth. It is caused either by the abnormal position of the foetus in the uterus or by defect in the process of formation of structure in foetal life. The most common congenital dislocation is the dislocation of hip joint.
A type of dislocation occurring due to joint diseases e.g. inflammation, pus formation or tubercular infection and other nerve disorders
When the head of the bone completely subluxates from its normal position

Arabic_term: خلع غير تام/ خلع غير كامل/ خلع غير مكمل
NAMC_TERM: Khal‘ Ghayr Tāmm/ Khal‘ Ghayr Kāmil/ Khal‘ Ghayr Mukammal
Long_definition: When the head of the bone partially subluxates from its normal position.
When there is injury of the skin with dislocation.
When there is injury of vessels and bones with dislocation. This is a complicated type of dislocation.
When there is fracture with dislocation of bone.
Partial displacement of the bone from its joint.
Breaches in the continuity of muscles and other tissues of the body.
Discontinuity of skin and mucous membrane which is exposed outside.
Wounds which are produced by sharp instruments or objects.
Wounds caused by pointed sharp objects that involve skin and underlying tissues.
Wounds with irregular and jagged edges and characterised by the massive destruction of tissues.
Wounds having six edges.
Closed blunt wounds not involving skin.
Wounds caused by the bite of poisonous animals.
Wounds caused by burn.
Wounds that are infected and suppurated.
Wounds that are not infected and not suppurated.
A systemic disease associated with the presence, multiplication and formation of septic emboli in the blood.
A condition which results from the spread of bacterial products or toxins in the blood stream.
Presence of pus in the blood with pyemic abscesses. This condition is marked by fevers, chills, sweating and abscess in various parts of the body.
Breach in the continuity of the epithelial membrane is known as ulcer. It is caused by some injury, abscess and skin eruptions.
A type of ulcer caused by pus forming bacteria.
A type of ulcer caused by specific causative organism e.g. syphilitic ulcers, tuberculous ulcers, etc.
A type of ulcer that doesn’t heal easily or the healing is delayed.
A type of ulcer accompanied with pain.
A type of ulcer not accompanied with pain.
A type of ulcer that is easily healed.
A type of ulcer that is difficult to heal e.g. varicose ulcer.
A grave kind of ulcer, named after the person Khayrūn who first suffered from this.
A type of ulcer that has the tendency to spread by the continous discharge of pus.
A type of ulcer found on the skin surface as a scar mark with dark sloughing. It is caused due to the accumulation of burnt black bile.
A type of ulcer found in bed ridden patients. These ulcers are produced by the pressure, injury, anaemia and wet surface of the bed.
Ulcer which is clean.
Ulcer in which infection persists.
Ulcer in which there is plenty of viscid fluids.
Ulcer in which there is putrified material.
Ulcerating basal cell carcinoma of the skin.

Name English: ulcer, associated with falling of hair around it
Long_definition: Ulcer which is associated with falling of hair around it.
Ulcers with continuous discharge from them.
Ulcers which are hot in nature.
Ulcers which are cold in nature.
An ulcer found on the legs because of stasis or stagnation of blood in the veins.

Primarily, there is appearance of small papule on the skin. Later, there is increase in redness and burning. After about 10-15 days there is a formation of ulcer with intense red papule and crusts.There is a continous discharge from this ulcer and these are difficult to heal.
Ūdhīma is a Greek word meaning phlegmatic swelling. It is formed by the predominance of phlegm. It causes pitting on the site of swelling.

A type of parasitic disease. It starts with an eruption on the skin of the leg or hand or extremities or trunk more commonly on the calf muscles. After the ulceration of eruptions, a red thread like worm comes out from it which is quite long and its length gradually increases. This worm usually resides beneath the skin and creeps. There is pain at the site of worm. Sometimes, the number of these worms is about 40-50.
It is a Greek word meaning decomposition of organs. It is a decomposed inflammation which is caused by putrified blood or without blood.

An initial stage of Shafāqalūs, in which colour of the affected part slightly changes due to decayed and putrified blood. There is no loss of sensitivity of the part. The innate energy of the part remains preserved i.e. there is no destruction of tissues of the affected part.
A type of gangrene caused by chronic obstruction of the arteries. In this condition the decayed organ becomes hard, dry and wrinkled. The colour of organ changes to dark brown.
Gangrene caused by obstruction of veins or occlusion of arteries abruptly.
A rapidly spreading gangrene in which decaying process is fast. The colour of the affected part changes to yellow, green,black and leads to toxaemia.
A type of gangrene that occurs as a result of complication of some other disease. It is of many types.
A type of gangrene that occurs as a result of obstruction of vessels.
A type of gangrene that occurs in old age.
A type of gangrene that occurs due to the pressure of thrombus in the arteries.
A type of gangrene that occurs due to diabetes.
A type of gangrene that occurs due to trauma or injury of a part.
A type of gangrene which develops when a part is exposed to extreme cold for a long duration of time.
An acute infective type of gangrene which spreads very rapidly and is accompanied with swelling.
A spot, rash or other mark appearing suddenly on the skin. According to content, they are classified into different types.

According to Galen, small pustules are formed by the accumulation of morbid fluids which after being deviated towards skin gets collected in between the muscular layer and skin.This usually appears in those persons who have thick skin.
A type of eruption which occurs on the external ear or pinna. These are small, red coloured papules. These are caused by the derangement of blood, mixed with fluids.
Big sized, black coloured eruptions from which black pus is discharged. They mostly occur at the calf muscles. These are caused due to the accumulation of morbid humours in the calf muscles.
A type of abnormal eruptions which occur at nape of the neck. These are multiple, large and painful pustules. These are caused by acrid humour.
A type of abnormal eruptions which appear on face and cheeks in the form of hard pustules with redness around them. It involves the whole face in later stage.
Persistent eruptions on skin and mucous membrane.
Black coloured large papules which occur on calf musles and are suppurated.
An ulcerated papule found on the cheeks and vagina. It resembles with mulberry. It occurs beneath the skin.
Small, white coloured pustules with roots as hard as tumour. Their outer ends are filled with pus. These are melancholic in nature.
A type of pustules that appear at different sites. These are due to accumulation of acrid blood in the body.
Fluctuant swelling which are more or less circular in shape and are filled with fluid or viscous material.
Hard nodules present in an organ. These do not resolve even after a long period of time.
This is caused by the viscosity and derangement of the blood. There is predominance of black bile in the blood. Due to this, it accumulates in the organs causing swelling and inflammation.
It denotes the swelling of the organ due to the accumulation of viscous humours resulting in distension of the organs.
In this type of swelling, gas gets accumulated in the spaces of organs. This is lighter in weight and cannot be pressed with pressure.
Acute swelling of the organs characterised by severe clinical features.
Swelling caused by cold humours.
Swelling occurs without putrifaction.

Swelling that occurs due to the involvement of humours. It may be Damawī, Balghamī, Ṣafrāwī and Sawdāwī. When it involves blood it is known as Falghamūnī. When it involves yellow bile, it is known as Namla wa Ḥumra. When it involves black bile, it is known as Saqīrūs and when it involves phlegm it is known as Waram Rikhw.

Swelling of an organ due to the involvement of blood. As this swelling is warm in nature and is accompanied with burning, it is included in Waram Ḥārr (acute inflammation) but most of the time its matter is blood. In this condition the site of swelling is distended, with severe pain which aggravates on pressure. This is more marked in the vascular organs.
A transudative type of swelling.

A type of chronic inflammation or swelling which is due to accumulation of black bile characterized by stony hardness and loss of sensation and pain. It starts with small swelling which later grows and sometimes it may transform into cancer. It is of two types: Saqīrūs Khāliṣ and Saqīrūs Ghayr Khāliṣ.
A type of movable swelling with varying size from gram seed to watermelon.
A tumour, formed by the tissues of some organs. These are often encapsulated and do not spread. They don’t recur once removed.
A type of spreading and recurring tumour. Sometimes these become ulcerated from which pus and other material comes out. These are accompanied with anaemia and general weakness of the body.
The content of this type of tumour is fat which is white in colour and very hard and can’t be compressed on pressure.
The content of this type of tumour resembles with that of honey. It is somewhat liquid and yellow in colour.
Contents of this type of tumour resemble with Ardhāla i.e. a semi solid preparation made of flour and clarified butter.
Contents of this type of tumour resemble a curry named Shīrāzī which is white in colour and prepared with milk. It is somewhat similar to Ḥarīra.
A tumour that occurs in face, urinary bladder, intestine, nerves and spinal cord. Content of this tumour are phlegm or phlegm like humour.
A tumour that occurs in retina, brain and spinal cord. It is composed of cartilaginous matter.
Contents of this type of tumour are fibrous and hair like. It is commonly found in the uterus.
A type of tumour found on the margins of long bones and it causes pain when it compresses the nerve.
A type of tumour that is found around the teeth.
A rare type of tumour which occurs on face or neck. This is formed from nerve fibres along with other tissues. It is not a fatal condition.
A type of tumour which occurs in the blood vessels.
A type of tumour which occurs in uterus, prostate glands and GI tract.
A type of tumour which arises from bone marrow.
Tumour of the glands.
A type of tumour of semi lunar shape.

Its literal meaning is “crab” as it sticks to its prey like a crab. It is a type of malignant, melancholic swelling which can occur anywhere in the body. It starts with a small swelling which gradually increases with time. It spreads very rapidly and the roots of this swelling are deep with prominent vessels. Sometimes it appears due to the accumulation of burnt yellow bile and phlegm.
This malignant swelling is associated with ulceration and purulent discharge.

Its literal meaning is ‘ant’. These are one or more small red papules which cause severe burning and itching. This burning is similar to ant bite. These red papules spread along one line like ant that is why it is known as Namla or Sā‘iya. Its cause is the preponderance of bile or any abnormality in bile. It is of many types.
When the red papules affect only the upper surface of the skin and cause burning and itching. It is due to the accumulation of yellow bile under the skin.
When the papules get ulcerated these are known as Namla Muta’akkila.
When the red papules appear on the lips, crusting appears with in 6-8 days and they finally disappear.

When the red papules appear on the prepuce internally or externally. These cause severe itching and form blisters and internal papules which later changes into ulcers. External papules disappear within 7-8 days. Sometimes papules appear gradually which causes hardening of the prepuce.

In this condition eruptions appear on the line of distribution of nerves which changes into transparent papules and causes severe burning and itching. Later, blisters with crusting appear within 10-14 days.
In this condition, papules occur along the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve. These are generally accompanied by conjunctivitis and sometimes by keratitis.
A type of erythema in which vesicles occur. It is devoid of neuralgic pain. It usually subsides in four weeks.
In this condition the papules are millet shaped. These are white in colour with red roots. They cause burning, pain and swelling at the site.

Eruptions of the skin in the form of bullous, containing watery fluid and sometimes blood. These resemble the blisters which are produced after burns. This is caused by the dilution of blood and collection of fluid beneath the skin which later on takes the shape of blisters. It is of two types: acute and chronic.
Blisters which occur during childhood. These blisters rupture quickly and black crust appears on them followed by the formation of cicatrix.
Sometimes blisters are accompanied with infection and decomposition of the tissues. This condition leads to weakness and death of the patient.

Initially a blister appears on the upper trunk then gradually small blisters appear around it which later join and yellow crust appears on these blisters. A specific type of smell occurs in the patient.
Blisters containing gases in place of fluids.
Collection of flat red papules which causes severe burning sensation resembling to fire burn. It immediately forms crusting of brown colour. It is caused by predominance of black bile.

Eruptions of the skin which are encrusted immediately after appearance. There is intense burning in these eruptions. There are reddish greenish lines on the skin at the site of eruptions which resemble flame of fire. Hence it is called Nār Fārsī. Nār Fārsī, is classified into many types depending on the nature of eruptions. These are plain, reddish, vesicular, pustular, hard and Shuqāqī.

The word Ṭā‘ūn is an altered form of the Unani word Ṭay‘ūn meaning inflammation of lymph glands of the body. It is the swelling of the body which is accompanied with severe pain and burning. The colour of the skin surrounding the swelling becomes blackish, reddish, bluish or greenish. It usually spreads in the form of epidemic. It is caused by poisonous substances which destroy the affected organs.

Inflammation accompanied with swelling of the lymph glands of axilla, groin and neck. Before swelling there is high grade fever with rigors and chills, headache, nausea and vomiting. But after the appearance of swelling of lymph glands these symptoms subside.

The most severe and grave type of plague. In this condition there is generalized swelling of all the lymph glands of the body accompanied with fever, delirium, vomiting, diarrhoea and haemorrhage. Patient suffering from this type usually dies within 24 hours.
It is a highly infectious type of plague in which infection spreads through droplets characterized by high fever, cough, passing of blood while coughing. This type has a bad prognosis.
A gangrenous ulcer of any part of the body.

Inflammation, swelling and enlargement of the lymph glands of axilla and groin due to infections such as syphilis, tuberculosis, gonorrhoea, etc. It is due to the collection of morbid material from the organs. It can also be due to some ulcers of the skin.

A type of small abscess which can occur anywhere on the body. Initially it is red and causes severe pain. The condition mostly occurs in travellers and persons who do more physical and sternuous work.

Collection of fluid in the lymphatic channels due to their obstruction as a result of which the legs become swollen. But unlike varicose veins these channels are not visible under the skin. The leg and foot of the patient resemble with that of an elephant
Dilatation, elongation and torsion of the veins which affects the legs of the patient. This is usually common in person who used to stand for a long time.
Burn injury with dry heat e.g flame, heated metal and heated objects.
Burning with lightning and thunder bolt.
Burning of the skin on exposure to strong sun rays.
Burn injury due to direct contact with the secretion of Balādur (Semecarpus anacardium).
Burn injury with radiation.

A parasitic disease in which there is worm infestation in the subcutaneous space. This worm travels inside the body and can reach up to the head. This travelling causes intense pain and burning. From head it usually comes out through the eyes and causes blindness. It can reach to any part of the body. Its treatment is either ligation and incision of a part to remove this worm or cauterization.

A condition where Waram Rīḥī travels in the body very fast like mercury. Its treatment is to ligate that particular part and cauterize it, otherwise cupping with fire can also be done on that part. If the affected part is difficult to locate then drugs which are used to evacuate phlegm from the body are used. This disease is seen in non-Arab females.
Abrasion of the skin which may be caused by friction of some hard objects on the skin.
Abrasion of the skin caused by improper shoes and leather socks.
Abrasion of the skin caused by tightening of rope or any ligature.
A chronic disease like tuberculosis which causes deformity of the organs and loss of organs in later stage. Sometimes, in few patients it is accompanied with ulceration of the body.
In this type of leprosy there is no nodule formation but there is loss of sensation of organs. It is more commonly seen in tropical countries.
In this type of leprosy there is nodule formation with deformity of organs. It is more commonly seen in cold countries.

Emaciation or cachexia that may be caused by 1. nutritional deficiencies e.g. intake of low fat diet 2. weakness of the faculties of stomach due to its cold temperament 3. after discontinuation of regular and strenuous exercise 4. bilious temperament of an individual 5. dysfunctioning of liver 6. worm infestation 7. excessive catabolism e.g. in case of chronic debilitating illnesses, excessive grief, sorrow, etc.
Obesity is caused by leading a sedentary life and intake of fatty diets.
A type of cachexia of the body in which there is massive dryness of the body without fever. The patient looks like an old man in this condition.

Protrusion of an organ or a part of the organ through an abnormal opening from the abdominal cavity to outside. It can be caused by increased abdominal pressure due to chronic cough, pregnancy, chronic constipation, etc. It can also be due to injury or incision in the peritoneum.
Protrusion of a part of intestine from the inguinal canal into the scrotum.
Protrusion of a part of intestine into the inguinal canal.
A type of hernia which can be reduced back to its original position by manipulation.
A type of hernia which can not be reduced to its original position by manipulation.
A type of hernia in which the herniated part is so tightly constricted in the orifice that blood supply of the hernial sac gets disturbed leading to its gangrene.
A type of hernia in which the herniated part gets inflamed.
A type of hernia in which there is obstruction in the hernial sac because of extramural cause.
A type of hernia in which the herniated part comes out from deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal.
A type of hernia in which the herniated part comes out through the hesselbach’s triangle.
A type of hernia which is present since birth . In this type, there is herniation of intestine in the scrotum
A type of hernia in which a part of intestine herniates through the umbilicus. This occurs mostly in children , old people and young multipara women.
A type of hernia, in which a part of stomach herniates through the opening in the abdominal wall.
A type of hernia, in which a structure pushes through the wall of the femoral canal.
Displacement of abdominal muscle around umbilicus.

Name English: A hard melancholic swelling with loss of sensation.
Long_definition: A hard melancholic swelling with loss of sensation.
Inflammation of peritoneum. It is of two types: acute and chronic.
Bite of any type of snake. It is characterized by inflammation, shivering, syncope, excessive perspiration, pale eyes, swelling and boil at the site of bite.
It is characterized by acute firm swelling of the organ involved, piercing sensation followed by cold perspiration, trembling of lips, vomiting, shivering, cold extremities, etc.
It is characterized by redness, swelling and pain at the site of bite.
It is characterized by bluish and greenish discoloration of the skin at the site of bite, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.
It is characterized by cold sweat, itching all over the body, etc.
It is characterized by slight pain and itching initially which subsides after some time.

It is characterized by severe pain, extreme burning sensation in the body, acute glossitis, heaviness of tongue, shivering and numbness of organs. Sometimes there is black discoloration of skin at the site of bite followed by putrefaction.
Bite of beaver is considered to be of grave consequences if bitten by a hungry beaver.
It is characterized by convulsions and inflammation of tongue.
Human bite is the most dangerous when it is bitten by a hungry person.
Bite of wolf causes wounds which may putrefy if not managed properly.
It is characterized by severe pain and greenish discoloration of skin at the site of bite.

It is characterized by wound at the site of bite with pain. Gradually, the patient experiences nightmare, depression, fear of water, convulsions and tetanus. When this condition lasts the patient develops confusion. He often runs to bite other persons and whenever he/she sees water he/she starts to shiver.
It is a general term used for bites by scorpions, wasps, spiders, etc.

It is characterized by excessive vomiting and diarrhoea, abdominal colic, asphyxia, dryness of mouth, heaviness and blackish discoloration of tongue, retrosternal burning, palpitation, redness of eyes, increased temperature of the body, etc. The cause of death in this type of poisoning is hepatic diarrhoea and haemetemesis.
It is characterized by abdominal pain, severe tenesmus, bloody diarrhoea, heaviness of tongue, heaviness of stomach, retention of urine and oedema all over the body.
Its clinical features are same as Sammiyat-i-Sīmāb (mercury poisoning).

It is characterized by generalized oedema of the body, breathlessness, sometimes asphyxia; colour of the skin is similar to that of Usrub (lead), colic, retention of urine, dryness of mouth, heaviness of tongue, stomach and intestine, etc.
Its clinical features are same as that of Sammiyat-i-Murdārsaṉg (litharge poisoning).
Its clinical features are headache, cancrum oris, dryness of mouth and abdominal pain.
Its clinical features are swollen lips, glossitis, exophthalmos, frequent respiration, halitosis, shock, weakness of calf muscles with difficulty in walking, etc.
Severe restlessness and hiccups. Sometimes there is severe diarrhoea occasionally mixed with blood.
Its clinical features are severe burning in mouth, stomach and intestine, boils and eruptions in mouth and lips and high grade fever, etc.
Its clinical features are severe restlessness, feeling of severe burning sensation in the body and flatulence.
Its clinical features are severe diarrhoea, asphyxia, palpitation, burning of tongue, excessive belching, flatulence etc. These are followed by convulsion, trembling and death.
Its clinical features are syncope and nausea.
Its clinical features are vertigo, giddiness, redness of eyes, intoxication and deep sleep. Patient will have cold sweats, pulsus parvus and shallow breathing, delirium, etc.
Its clinical features are same as that of Sammiyat-i-Jawz Māthil. Moreover, there will be tetany, deafness, pruritus, deep sleep, etc.
Its clinical features are flaccidity of organs, glossitis, chelitis, redness of eyes, vertigo and giddiness, diminished vision, breathlessness, pruritus, intoxication, delirium, etc.
Its clinical features are diminished vision, cold extremities, severe distension, heaviness in body and thighs. Later it may cause convulsions, asphyxia and death.
Its clinical features are same as that of Sammiyat-i-Ajwā’in Khurāsānī.
A power endowed by nature to every individual for self preservation which regulates its normal functions. It is the administrator, protector and healer of the body.
The essential factors in association with the structure and functions of the body i.e. Arkān, Mizāj, Akhlāṭ, A‘ḍā’, Arwāḥ, Quwā and Af‘āl. Each of them is must to sustain the body.
Simple bodies which are primary substances of human and non-human bodies. They can not be subdivided into bodies which have different forms. Their intermixture results in different forms in nature.

One of the four primary substances found in nature, bearing the natural properties of heat and dryness. The role it plays in the construction of things is to mature, refine and intermingle with all things.

One of the four primary substances found in nature, bearing the natural properties of heat and moisture. Its effect and value in (the world of) creation is to rarefy and render things finer, lighter, more delicate, softer and better able to move to the lighter spheres. Sometimes, this term is also used for the gases arising from different organs in their pathological state.

One of the four primary substances found in nature, bearing the natural properties of cold and moistness. Its purpose in (the world of) creation lies in the fact that it lends itself readily to dispersion and consequently assumes any non-permanent shape.

One of the four primary substances found in nature bearing the natural properties of cold and dryness. Its purpose in the (world of) creation is to fix and hold the being together into a compacted form

A quality that is produced by action and reaction of opposite qualities of elements which are broken up in small particles in order to facilitate their mixing. When these components interact among themselves, a condition is produced, which is found in equal proportion in all the particles of the compound.
The temperament in which the hot and dry physical properties dominate the other two physical properties i.e. cold and moist.
The temperament in which the hot and moist physical properties dominate the other two physical properties i.e. cold and dry.
The temperament in which the cold and dry physical properties dominate the other two physical properties i.e. hot and moist.
The temperament in which the cold and moist properties dominate on the other two physical properties i.e. hot and dry
The fluids of the body that serve the functions of nutrition, growth and repair of the organs.
One of the four basic humours, red in color bearing hot and wet temperament. It is excellent among all the humours.
One of the four basic humours which is white in colour and bears cold and wet temperament. It is next to sanguine humour in excellence
One of the four basic humours. It is yellow in colour and has hot and dry temperament. It is next to phlegm in excellence.
One of the four basic humours. It is black coloured and has cold and dry temperament.
A light gaseous substance found in organs and fluids of the body and performs various important functions. It is obtained from the interaction of inspired air with Akhlāṭ Laṭīfa.
The Rūḥ (pneuma) which is found in the organs of psychic faculty and its centre is brain.
The Rūḥ (pneuma) which is found in the organs of vital faculty and its centre is heart.
The Rūḥ (pneuma) which is found in the organs of natural faculty and its centre is liver.
The solid parts of the body which are derived primarily from the coarse humours. These are the essential tools to accomplish vivid functions.
The organs in which the visible and perceptible parts carry the same name and definitions as the whole organ e.g. flesh, nerve, etc.
The organs in which the comprising parts irrespective of size differ in nature as well as name for the whole organ.
A natural and specialized ability of the body for the performance of its specific function.
The natural and specialized power which is furnished in an individual for digestion and assimilation of food and evacuation of waste from the body.
The power which is furnished in an individual for the intellectual, sensory and motor function of the body.
The power which is furnished in an individual to receive other powers essential for the survival.
The natural and specialized powers which are furnished in an individual for preservation of its species.
The bodily activity essential for fulfilling the objectives of the body. It is performed by the organs and also testimony to the presence of powers in them.
The functions which are vital for the survival. These are performed by Quwā Ḥaywāniyya and executed by A‘ḍā’ Ḥaywāniyya.
The functions that are performed by the psychic faculty of the body. These are performed by Quwā Nafsāniyya and executed by A‘ḍā’ Nafsāniyya.
The functions which are essential to energize all the powers and develop the organs. These are performed by Quwā Ṭabī‘iyya and executed by A‘ḍā’ Ṭabī‘iyya.
The state of health in which the structure and functions of the body are in normal state.
The intermediate state of the body, in between, the state of health and the state of disease. It is a state of neither health nor disease
The four natural properties or qualities associated with matter. These are hot, cold, moist and dry.
The two active properties i.e. hot and cold.
One of the four physical properties naturally associated with matter.
One of the four physical properties naturally associated with matter.
The two passive physical properties i.e. moist and dry
One of the four physical properties naturally associated with matter.
One of the four physical properties naturally associated with matter.
The innate heat of the body regulated by medicatrix naturae for the normal functioning of the body.
The term used for the process of digestion and transformation of the food particles to become the parts of the body.
The four different types of digestion i.e. Haḍm Mi‘dī, Haḍm Kabidī, Haḍm ‘Urūqī, Haḍm ‘Uḍwī which the food particles have to go through for the purpose of assimilation in the body.
The first stage of food digestion which occurs inside the alimentary canal to form chime.
The second stage of food digestion which takes place at the site of liver to form chyle.
The third stage of digestion which takes place inside the vessels. This helps in the assimilation of food so that it becomes the part of the body.
The fourth stage of digestion which takes place in the organs.
The temperament of an individual in different phases of life.
The temperament of human being which is considered to be the most perfect and noble in comparison with all other species. This temperament is inclined towards heat.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Dam (sanguine) in the body. It is hot and moist. The individuals with this type of temperament have strong built, full pulse, pinkish colour of skin, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Balgham (phlegm) in the body. It is cold and moist. The individuals with this type of temperament have fatty body, excessive sleep, whitish colour of skin, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Ṣafrā’ (yellow bile) in the body. It is hot and dry. The individuals with this type of temperament have thin built, yellowish colour of the skin, rapid pulse, etc.

A type of temperament caused by the predominance of Sawdā’ (black bile) in the body. It is cold and dry. The individuals with this type of temperament have thin built with prominent veins, blackish color of the skin, etc.

sanguine humour, devoid of  its normal qualities either through change of temperament such as getting hot or cold or due to admixture with the humours derived from outside or produced within the sanguine humour, e.g., when a part of it gets putrefied, the lighter portion is converted into abnormal yellow bile and the heavier portion into abnormal black bile
phlegm devoid of basic characters of normal phlegm
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is saline or alkaline in taste and inclined towards heat and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is sour in taste and inclined towards coldness and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is tasteless, very immature and quite cold
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is gallic in taste and inclined towards coldness and dryness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is sweet in taste and inclined towards heat and moistness
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having  watery consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having extremely thick consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having mucoid consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having vitreous consistency
one of the abnormal types of phlegm, having foul smell, produced by sepsis/infection/putrefaction
yellow bile that becomes abnormal either due to addition of  extraneous material or alteration in its own composition
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of thick phlegm
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of thin phlegm
one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the admixture of burnt black bile

one of the abnormal types of yellow bile, produced by the combustion of ordinary yellow bile, resulting in development of leek green colour due to mixing of the burnt material  with the original yellow bile
the hottest and the most lethal of all abnormal types of yellow bile produced due to extreme combustion of leek green bile
black bile produced either by the combustion of black bile itself or combustion of any of the other three humours, i.e., sanguine, phlegm, yellow bile
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of sanguine
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of yellow bile
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of phlegm
one of the abnormal types of black bile, produced by the combustion  of black bile itself
single disease  is produced either due to the abnormality of temperament or composition or breach in continuity

when the heat dominates abnormally in the body

when dryness dominates abnormally in the body

roughness of the surface which should be smooth, e.g. roughness of internal surface of trachea
smoothness of the surface which should be rough, e.g. smoothness of internal surface of stomach

increase in the size, e.g. elephantiasis
